questions.text: Annular lesions are seen in all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Urticaria Pigmentosa:

  • Urticaria pigmentosa is a form of mastocytosis that primarily affects the skin.
  • It presents with urticarial lesions that heal with hyperpigmentation.
  • Any minute trauma or stroking of lesions leads to the development of  urticarial lesions. However, these lesions are not annular.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D: Annular lesions are seen in Tinea corporis, Pityriasis Rosea, and Porokeratosis.

questions.text: The involvement of which of the following results in the given condition below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Lymphatics

  • The image shows massive swelling of the lower limb with skin thickening and folds, characteristic of elephantiasis.

  • Elephantiasis results from lymphatic obstruction, leading to chronic lymphedema and fibrosis.

  • The most common cause is lymphatic filariasis due to Wuchereria bancrofti infection.

  • Non-infectious causes include congenital lymphedema, malignancy, and post-surgical lymphatic damage.

Lymphedema and Elephantiasis

Feature

Lymphedema (Elephantiasis)

Cause

Lymphatic obstruction (Filariasis, malignancy, surgery, congenital defects)

Appearance

Massive swelling, skin thickening, warty texture

Stages

1. Pitting edema (early) 2. Non-pitting edema (late) 3. Fibrosis & skin changes (severe)

Complications

Skin infections, ulceration, restricted mobility

Diagnosis

Clinical examination, ultrasound, lymphoscintigraphy

Treatment

Limb elevation, compression therapy, antibiotics for infections, diethylcarbamazine (for filariasis)

Arteries (Option A): Incorrect because arterial disease causes ischemia, pain, and ulceration, not massive swelling.

Vein (Option B): Incorrect because venous insufficiency leads to varicose veins and stasis ulcers, not elephantiasis.

DVT (Option D): Incorrect because deep vein thrombosis (DVT) presents with acute unilateral swelling, pain, and erythema, not chronic massive lymphedema.

questions.text: A school-going child who had applied henna comes to dermatology OPD with the following lesions. Her mother also complains that she has a habit of scratching her hand whenever she is studying. What is the diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Dermatitis artefacta

  • Dermatitis artefacta is a condition characterized by self-inflicted skin lesions, consciously or unconsciously caused by the individual. It is considered a psychiatric disorder rather than a primary skin disease.
  • The lesions in dermatitis artefacta often have unusual or bizarre patterns and may not follow the typical distribution or characteristics of known dermatological conditions.
  • These lesions may appear in unusual shapes, patterns, or locations that are not consistent with typical henna reactions or allergic contact dermatitis.
  • Treatment involves a multidisciplinary approach involving dermatologists, psychologists, and psychiatrists to address the underlying psychological issues and provide appropriate care and support to the individual.
  • In the case of henna application, if the child deliberately scratches or traumatizes the skin in the area where henna was applied, it can result in skin lesions that resemble a dermatitis reaction. The child may create patterns or designs by scratching the skin, leading to the appearance of lesions.

Incorrect Options:

Contact dermatitis due to henna (Option A): Could be a possible differential diagnosis, as henna can sometimes cause an allergic reaction in certain individuals. However, in this case, the option "dermatitis artefacta" suggests that the lesions are self-induced rather than a true allergic contact dermatitis.

Polymorphous light eruption (Option C): (PMLE) is a type of photodermatitis that occurs in response to exposure to sunlight or artificial ultraviolet (UV) light. However, the given information about henna application does not align with the characteristic triggers of PMLE.

Vitiligo (Option D): Vitiligo is an autoimmune disorder and does not involve the intentional or self-inflicted creation of skin lesions.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of the condition affecting the hair, resulting in the following appearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Trichothiodystrophy

Trichothiodystrophy is a rare genetic disorder that affects the structure of the hair.

One of the characteristic features of Trichothiodystrophy is the presence of "tiger tail banding" when the hair is examined under polarized light microscopy. This term refers to alternating light and dark bands along the hair shaft, resembling the pattern of a tiger's tail.

  • Trichothiodystrophy is primarily characterized by brittle hair that is prone to breakage and has a characteristic appearance under the microscope.
  • Some key features of Trichothiodystrophy include:
    • Brittle Hair
    • Tiger Tail Banding
    • Variable Hair Color
    • Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities
    • Additional features may include dry and scaly skin, brittle nails, photosensitivity (sensitivity to sunlight), and ocular abnormalities.

Incorrect Options:

Trichorhexis nodosa (Option A): Trichorhexis nodosa is a hair shaft disorder characterized by nodules or nodes along the hair shaft. It does not typically show the specific "tiger tail banding" pattern seen in Trichothiodystrophy.

Trichorexis invaginata (Option B): Trichorexis invaginata, also known as "bamboo hair," is a condition in which the hair shaft is characterized by multiple invaginations or nodules. It does not present with the specific banding pattern seen in Trichothiodystrophy.

Monilethrix (Option D): Monilethrix is a hereditary hair disorder characterized by beaded hair shafts that resemble a necklace. It does not show the specific "tiger tail banding" pattern seen in Trichothiodystrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis for a child born with membranes around the body, ectropion, and eclabium, presenting with lesions on the face, trunk, and extremities, and brought to the OPD, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Harlequin ichthyosis

Explanation:

  • Harlequin ichthyosis is likely a diagnosis based on the image shown.

Harlequin Ichthyosis

Introduction

  • Harlequin ichthyosis is a rare, severe genetic skin disorder characterized by thick, armor-like scales covering the body at birth. It is an autosomal recessive condition caused by mutations in the ABCA12 gene, affecting lipid transport in the epidermis.

Pathophysiology

  • ABCA12 gene mutation leads to defective lipid transport, disrupting the skin barrier.
  • This results in thickened, hyperkeratotic plates with deep fissures, severe dehydration, and increased infection risk.

Features

  • Thick, diamond-shaped scales covering the body
  • Ectropion (everted eyelids) and eclabium (everted lips)
  • Contracted digits (hypoplastic fingers and toes)
  • Risk of severe dehydration, infections, and respiratory distress
  • Delayed skin shedding, improving with time but requiring lifelong care

Investigations & Diagnosis

  • Clinical examination based on characteristic features at birth
  • Genetic testing to confirm ABCA12 mutation
  • Skin biopsy (rarely needed) shows massive hyperkeratosis

Treatment

  • Neonatal intensive care (hydration, temperature regulation)
  • Emollients and keratolytics (e.g., petrolatum, urea, lactic acid) to soften scales
  • Oral retinoids (e.g., acitretin, isotretinoin) to reduce hyperkeratosis
  • Antibiotics for secondary infections
  • Lifelong skin care with moisturization and gentle exfoliation

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis:

Subtype

Clinical Features

Genetic Defect

Harlequin ichthyosis

Thick, plate-like scales covering the entire body

ABCA12 gene mutations

Lamellar ichthyosis (Option B)

Large thick scales, often present at birth

TGM1, ALOX12B, ALOXE3, or NIPAL4 gene mutations

Congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma (CIE)

Generalized redness, fine white scales

TGM1, ALOX12B, ALOXE3, or NIPAL4 gene mutations

Self-healing collodion baby

Membrane-like encasement at birth, followed by shedding

TGM1, ALOX12B, ALOXE3, or NIPAL4 gene mutations

Harlequin ichthyosis-like phenotypes

Variations resembling harlequin ichthyosis

Different genetic mutations, including PNPLA1, CYPF22, CASP14, CERS3, etc.

Incorrect Options:

Bathing suit ichthyosis (Option C): A rare variant of lamellar ichthyosis where scaling predominantly affects the trunk and proximal limbs, sparing other areas, resembling a "bathing suit" pattern.

Ichthyosis vulgaris (Option D): A common inherited skin disorder characterized by fine, dry, scaly skin, especially on the extensor surfaces, due to filaggrin gene mutations leading to impaired skin barrier function.

questions.text: A child accidentally took a bottle full of iron tablets. Which of the drugs is used as an antidote for iron poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Deferoxamine:
Explanation:

  • Acute iron poisoning can occur when a person ingests a toxic amount of iron tablets or other iron-containing substances.
  • Deferoxamine is a chelating agent that is used as the antidote for Acute iron poisoning.
  • Mechanism: Binds iron in the body and forms a stable complex that can be excreted through urine and faeces.
  • Deferoxamine helps to remove excess iron from the body and prevent its toxic effects.

Incorrect Options:

Luspatercept (Option B) is a medication used for the treatment of anemia in certain blood disorders and is not indicated for the treatment of iron poisoning.

Deferiprone (Option C) is an oral chelating agent used to treat iron overload in disorders like thalassemia. However, deferoxamine is the preferred antidote for acute iron poisoning.

DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic acid) (Option D) is another chelating agent used for heavy metal poisoning, but it is not the preferred antidote for iron poisoning. It is more commonly used for lead or mercury poisoning.

questions.text: A patient presents to the dermatology clinic reporting recurrent skin lesions as seen on the image. He describes that these lesions emerge within hours each time he takes NSAIDs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fixed drug eruptions

Explanation:

Fixed drug eruption features:

  • Recurrent lesions that appear within hours of taking NSAIDs
  • well-demarcated, erythematous patch
  • They recur at the same site upon re-exposure to the offending drug
  • Common triggers: NSAIDs, sulfa drugs, antibiotics
  • They heal with hyperpigmentation

Incorrect Options:

Erythema multiforme (Option B): Shows "target" or "iris" lesions with three zones of color, typically triggered by infections or drugs. But it does not typically recur on the same site after drug exposure and resolves differently .

 

Drug Induced Pigmentation (Option C): They present as persistent pigment changes (blue-grey, brown), not the acute, recurrent red plaques described here.

Herpes (Option D): Herpes produces blistering grouped lesions, often painful, and is unrelated to NSAID intake or this typical recurrence pattern.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with a skin lesion as shown below. Biopsy shows the presence of hyperkeratosis . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option b. Psoriasis is a persistent immune system skin jumble that is portrayed by the fast development and shedding of skin cells. As a result, thick, scaly skin patches are often reddish or pink in color and covered in silvery-white scales. Psoriasis can affect any part of the body, but the scalp, elbows, knees, lower back, and genitals are the most common locations

Incorrect choices:

Option a -Atopic dermatitis

  • A group of conditions known as neutrophilic dermatoses (NDs) are characterized by skin lesions for which a histological examination reveals a significant inflammatory infiltrate, primarily composed of neutrophils, without evidence of infection.Red, crusty, itchy, and flaky patches, resembling oval or circular patches on the skin, are typical manifestations of atopic dermatitis.
  • Option c. Pemphigus vulgaris is an uncommon immune system problem that influences the skin and mucous layers. Painful blisters and sores form on the skin as well as inside the mouth, nose, and genital area, indicating this condition.
  • Option d. Pemphigus foliaceus is a skin and mucous membrane-affecting autoimmune disease. The development of crusty, scaly lesions or blisters on the skin, particularly on the face, scalp, and chest, is a sign of this condition. An autoimmune reaction in which the immune system makes antibodies that attack the proteins that hold skin cells(desmoglein-1) together is what causes pemphigus foliaceus.

Correct option : C

  • Humby's knife: This is the correct option. Humby's knife is a surgical instrument commonly used in plastic surgery used for harvesting Skin Graft

Incorrect options:

Option A Single cutting razor: This is an incorrect option. A single cutting razor typically refers to a handheld razor used for shaving or hair removal. It is not the instrument shown in the image.

Option B. Double cutting razor: This is an incorrect option. A double cutting razor is not a specific surgical instrument, but it can refer to a type of razor blade that has cutting edges on both sides. It is not the instrument shown in the image.

Option D. Finochietto knife: This is an incorrect option. Finochietto knife is not a commonly used surgical instrument, and it is not the instrument shown in the image.

questions.text: What is the most suitable approach to minimize the likelihood of keloid recurrence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option : A

  •  Intralesional steroids: This is the correct option. Intralesional steroid injections are commonly used in the management of keloids. Steroids, such as triamcinolone acetonide, are injected directly into the keloid to help reduce inflammation, shrink the scar tissue, and inhibit the overproduction of collagen. This can help prevent keloid recurrence after treatment.

Incorrect Options:

Option B:  Surgery: This is an incorrect option. Surgical removal of a keloid can be performed, but it carries a risk of keloid recurrence, as the surgical incision itself can trigger the formation of new keloid tissue. Surgery alone is not usually sufficient to prevent keloid recurrence, and it is often combined with other treatments like steroid injections or radiation therapy.

Option C: Cryotherapy: This is an incorrect option. Cryotherapy involves freezing the keloid with liquid nitrogen to destroy the abnormal tissue. While cryotherapy can be effective in reducing the size of the keloid, it may not address the underlying cause and is not considered the most reliable method for preventing keloid recurrence.

Option D: Electrocoagulation: This is an incorrect option. Electrocoagulation involves using an electric current to destroy the keloid tissue. While it can be used as a treatment for keloids, it is not considered the primary method for preventing keloid recurrence.

questions.text: Identify the penile lesion shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Pearly penile papule: Pearly penile papules are small, dome-shaped bumps that appear around the corona of the penis.
    • They are considered a normal anatomical variant and are not associated with any infection or disease.
    • The lesion shown in the image closely resembles the appearance of pearly penile papules.

Incorrect Options 

Option A. Genital wart: Genital warts are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) and typically appear as small, raised, cauliflower-like growths on the genital area. They can vary in size and may be pink, flesh-colored, or grayish in appearance. The lesion shown in the image does not resemble the typical appearance of genital warts.

Option C. Balanitis: Balanitis refers to inflammation of the glans penis, typically caused by an infection or irritation. It can result in redness, swelling, and discomfort of the penis. The lesion shown in the image does not exhibit signs of inflammation commonly seen in balanitis.

Option D. Sebaceous gland prominence: Sebaceous gland prominence, also known as Fordyce spots, refers to the visible sebaceous glands on the skin. They appear as small, yellowish or white bumps and are commonly found on the genitals and other areas of the body. The lesion shown in the image does not resemble the typical appearance of sebaceous gland prominence.

questions.text: Tzancksmear as shown in the image shows:
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • A Tzanck smear is a diagnostic test in dermatology that involves scraping the base of a skin lesion and examining the cells under a microscope. It helps in the diagnosis of various blistering disorders and viral infections. The given image shows Acantholytic cells, which are characterized by the loss of cell-to-cell adhesion, are typically seen in conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris, a blistering autoimmune disorder.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Acanthosis refers to the thickening of the epidermis, which can be seen in conditions such as psoriasis or acanthosis nigricans.

Option C: Smudge cells are abnormal lymphocytes seen in chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

Option D: Anaplasia refers to the loss of cellular differentiation and organization, typically seen in malignant tumors.

questions.text: A patient with fever and joint pain developed pigmentation on the nose after a few days of taking NSAIDs as shown below. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D. Chikungunya: Chikungunya is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes. It is characterized by symptoms such as high fever, joint pain, muscle pain, headache, and rash. The development of pigmentation on the nose after taking NSAIDs is not a typical feature of chikungunya. Other symptoms, such as joint pain and fever, are more indicative of this diagnosis.

 

Incorrect option:

Option A. Melasma: Melasma is a common skin condition characterized by brown or gray patches on the face, particularly on the cheeks, forehead, and upper lip. It is not associated with fever or joint pain, so it is not the correct diagnosis in this case.

Option B. Fixed drug eruption: Fixed drug eruption is a type of drug-induced skin reaction characterized by the development of well-defined, round or oval-shaped patches that recur in the same location each time the drug is taken. It typically presents as red or purplish lesions, but pigmentation on the nose is not a typical feature of fixed drug eruption.

OptionC. Lichen planus: Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition that can affect the skin, mucous membranes, hair, and nails. It presents as itchy, flat-topped, purplish bumps that may have white streaks or lines on them. Pigmentation on the nose is not a characteristic feature of lichen planus.

questions.text: What is the usual cause of a condition characterized by blistering and peeling of more than 30% of the body's surface area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • A disease associated with the occurrence of blistering and peeling of over >30% of the body surface area is usually caused by drugs. This condition is known as Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) or toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). SJS and TEN are severe skin reactions that can be life-threatening.
  • Both SJS and TEN are typically triggered by certain medications, most commonly antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). When a person has an adverse reaction to these medications, it can lead to widespread blistering and peeling of the skin, affecting more than 30% of the body surface area.

Incorrect Options:

Option A Viral infection: While certain viral infections can cause skin rashes and blistering, they are not typically associated with the extensive blistering and peeling of over >30% of the body surface area as seen in SJS or TEN. Viral infections that can cause skin rashes include herpes simplex virus, varicella-zoster virus (chickenpox and shingles), and measles, among others.

Option C Fungal infection: Fungal infections generally do not cause the extensive blistering and peeling seen in SJS or TEN. Fungal infections of the skin, such as tinea infections (ringworm), typically present as red, scaly, and itchy patches on the skin, rather than blistering and peeling.

Option D Autoimmunity: Autoimmune conditions can result in various skin manifestations, but they are not specifically associated with the extensive blistering and peeling seen in SJS or TEN. Autoimmune blistering disorders, such as pemphigus and bullous pemphigoid, may cause blistering, but they do not typically lead to the widespread involvement of over >30% of the body surface area.
